text: And she made haste, and let down her pitcher from her shoulder, and said, Drink, and I will give thy camels drink also: so I drank, and she made the camels drink also.
text_kjv: And she made haste, and let down her pitcher from her shoulder, and said, Drink, and I will give thy camels drink also: so I drank, and she made the camels drink also.
text_niv: “She quickly lowered her jar from her shoulder and said, ‘Drink, and I’ll water your camels too.’ So I drank, and she watered the camels also.
text_esv: She quickly let down her jar from her shoulder and said, ‘Drink, and I will give your camels drink also.’ So I drank, and she gave the camels drink also.
text_nlt: She quickly lowered her jug from her shoulder and said, ‘Yes, have a drink, and I will water your camels, too!’ So I drank, and then she watered the camels.
text_msg: She didn't hesitate. She held out her jug and said, 'Drink; and when you're finished I'll also water your camels.' I drank, and she watered the camels.
text_nasb: 'She quickly lowered her jar from her [shoulder], and said, 'Drink, and I will water your camels also'; so I drank, and she watered the camels also.
context: Genesis 24 recounts Abraham's deliberate and divinely guided search for a wife for his son Isaac. This story unfolds within a patriarchal and kinship-based society where marriage served to secure lineage and land rights. Abraham, elderly and concerned about his son marrying a Canaanite woman, sends his trusted servant, likely Eliezer of Damascus, on a mission to his homeland in Mesopotamia. The significance of this location stems from Abraham's own origins in Ur of the Chaldees and the need to find a wife from among his own extended family or people. The journey itself was long and arduous, emphasizing the gravity of the task. Providing water, particularly in a desert environment, was an act of great hospitality and generosity. Camels, vital for transportation and trade, consumed large quantities of water, making the offer to water them a significant undertaking. Wells were central to community life, serving as gathering places and sources of sustenance, often privately owned or controlled by specific families or clans. The act of drawing water required considerable physical strength and effort. Rebekah's willingness to undertake this task, not just for Eliezer but also for his ten camels, immediately showcases her diligence, kindness, and capacity for hard work, all highly valued traits in a potential wife. The cultural importance of hospitality and duty to strangers cannot be overstated within the context of ancient Near Eastern societies. Showing kindness to travelers was not merely a courtesy but a moral obligation, often based on religious and tribal customs.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 24:46 highlights the providential hand of God in orchestrating events to fulfill His promises. Eliezer's prayer, specifically asking for a sign to identify the right woman, demonstrates his faith in God's guidance. Rebekah's act of offering water is not merely an act of kindness but a visible manifestation of God's answer to Eliezer's prayer. Her willingness to go above and beyond, offering to water the camels as well, underscores her character and aligns with the qualities that Abraham sought in a wife for Isaac. The verse emphasizes the importance of obedience to God's leading. Eliezer followed Abraham's instructions diligently, and Rebekah, unknowingly, fulfilled God's plan through her simple act of hospitality. This illustrates how God uses ordinary people and everyday situations to accomplish His divine purposes. The story is a foreshadowing of God's grace and initiative in salvation. Just as Abraham initiated the search for a bride for Isaac, God initiates the search for a bride (the Church) for His Son, Jesus Christ. Rebekah's willingness to leave her home and family to journey to a new land mirrors the believer's response to God's call to leave behind their old life and follow Him. Her kindness and selflessness are virtues that reflect the character of Christ and are exemplary for believers. The story subtly points to the future union of Christ and His Church, emphasizing love, commitment, and divine purpose.
application: In modern life, Genesis 24:46 serves as a powerful reminder of the importance of demonstrating genuine kindness and generosity to others, even strangers. In a world often characterized by self-centeredness and indifference, Rebekah's act of selfless service challenges us to consider how we can go above and beyond in showing compassion and meeting the needs of those around us. This verse encourages us to be observant of the opportunities God presents to us each day to be a blessing to someone. It reminds us that even seemingly small acts of kindness can have a significant impact on someone's life and can be used by God to fulfill His larger purposes. We can apply this principle by actively looking for ways to serve in our communities, whether it's volunteering our time, offering a helping hand to a neighbor in need, or simply being attentive to the emotional and spiritual needs of those around us. Furthermore, this verse teaches us the importance of being sensitive to the leading of the Holy Spirit. Just as Eliezer prayed for guidance and followed God's direction, we should seek God's wisdom in our decisions and be open to His promptings in our daily lives. The application of this verse also extends to our attitude towards work and responsibility. Rebekah's willingness to work hard and diligently to water the camels demonstrates the value of a strong work ethic and a willingness to take on challenging tasks. In our careers and personal lives, we should strive to approach our responsibilities with the same level of commitment and dedication. Ultimately, Genesis 24:46 encourages us to live lives that are characterized by love, service, and obedience to God's will.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the beautiful example of Rebekah's kindness and generosity. Help me to see opportunities to serve others with a willing heart, just as she did. Grant me a spirit of compassion and a desire to go above and beyond in meeting the needs of those around me. Lord, guide me by your Holy Spirit so that I may discern your leading in my daily life. Give me the courage to follow your direction, even when it leads me to unexpected places or requires me to step outside of my comfort zone. May my actions today be a reflection of your love and grace, and may they bring glory to your name. Help me to be attentive to the needs of those around me, and to offer practical help with a joyful spirit. I pray that you would use me to be a blessing to others, and that my life would be a testament to your goodness. In Jesus' name, Amen.
